title: Can something like the Coronavirus be the end of the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not a chance. Pandemics worse than the Coronavirus have occurred in the past and the human race has still survived. Certainly, the human race will still survive in the foreseeable future. Something in the medical field will happen that will halt the spread of the virus and life will continue. All that’s required is a scientific breakthrough in the medical field. This has happened before and I can assure you it will happen again. History keeps repeating itself. All that’s needed right now is for the human population to maintain isolation and wait patiently for the scientific breakthrough to happen. The waiting and the patience are all that is necessary for now. However isolation and maintaining distance are not the nature of human beings as you have witnessed in some instances where there have been cases of riots in some parts of the world, due to mental breakdowns caused by loneliness, hunger and lack of socialization. Humans are social animals so they can’t maintain lockdowns, quarantines, curfews and isolations for long. Something they will break. Then things will begin to happen unless a scientific breakthrough is found soon. It should be noted that there have been worse pandemics in history than the Coronavirus (COVID-19). Let’s look at 20 of the worst epidemics and pandemics in history: 1. Circa 3000 B.C. - An epidemic wipes out a prehistoric village in China. The village was later burned down and isolated for good. 2. 430 B.C. - An epidemic of pandemic proportions ravages the entire city of Athens for five years leaving a death toll as high as 100,000 people. 3. A.D. 165-180 - The Antonine Plague laid waste the Roman Empire killing more than 5 million people. It is thought that the plague (which may have been smallpox), was brought by the Roman soldiers returning from a war against Parthia. 4. A.D. 250-271 - The Plague of Cyprian is estimated to have killed 5,000 people a day in Rome alone. COVID-19 has not reached near that level in any city of the world. 5. A.D. 541-542 - The Justinian Plague wiped out an estimated 10% of the world population during the Byzantine Empire. 6. 1346-1353 - The Black Death traveled from Asia to Europe, leaving devastation in its wake. Some estimates suggest that it wiped out over half of Europe's population. 7. 1545-1548 - The Cocoliztli epidemic was a form of viral hemorrhagic fever that killed 15 million inhabitants of Mexico and Central America. 8. 16th century - The American Plagues are a cluster of Eurasian diseases brought to the Americas by European explorers. These illnesses, including smallpox, contributed to the collapse of the Inca and Aztec civilizations. Some estimates suggest that 90% of the indigenous population in the Western Hemisphere was killed off. 9. 1665-1666 - The Great Plague of London, also known as the Black Death or the bubonic plague ravaged the city of London and caused a mass exodus from London starting from 1665. By the time the plague ended, about 100,000 people in 18 months, including 15% of the population of London, had died. 10. 1720-1723 - The Great Plague of Marseille was likely caused by rat fleas. It spread quickly despite quarantine, killing as many as 100,000 people in Marseille and surrounding areas. It's estimated that up to 30% of the population of Marseille may have perished. 11. 1770-1772 - The Russian plague ravaged Moscow leaving as many as 100,000 people dead. Driven by terror, quarantined citizens erupted into a massive violence and riots that spread through the city culminating in the murder of Archbishop Ambrosius, who was encouraging crowds not to gather for worship. 12. 1793 - The Philadelphia yellow fever epidemic devastated the city of Philadelphia (the United States' capital at the time), when officials wrongly believed that slaves, predominantly of African origin were immune to the fever. 5,000 people died as a result. 13. 1889-1890 - The Flu pandemic reportedly broke out in Russia and spread rapidly throughout Europe and the rest of the world killing an estimated 1 million people, despite the fact that air travel didn't exist yet. 14. 1916 - The American polio epidemic started in New York City and caused 27,000 cases and 6,000 deaths in the United States. The disease mainly affects children and sometimes leaves survivors with permanent disabilities. 15. 1918-1920 - The Spanish influenza killed an estimated 500 million people from the South Seas to the North Pole. One-fifth of those died, with some indigenous communities pushed to the brink of extinction. 16. 1957-1958 - The Asian influenza pandemic reportedly broke out in China (coincidence?). The disease claimed more than 1 million lives. The virus that caused the pandemic was a strain of avian flu viruses. 17. 1981-present day - The AIDS pandemic and epidemic has claimed an estimated 35 million lives since it was first identified in 1981. 18. 2009-2010 - H1N1 Swine Flu pandemic was caused by a new strain of H1N1 that originated in Mexico in the spring of 2009 before spreading to the rest of the world. In one year, the virus infected as many as 1.4 billion people across the globe and killed between 151,700 and 575,400 people, according to the CDC. 19. 2014-2016 - The deadly Ebola epidemic that causes severe haemorrhage (bleeding) leading to painful death, ravaged West Africa and Congo, between 2014 and 2016, with 28,600 reported cases and 11,325 deaths. There is currently no cure for Ebola. 20. 2015-present day - The impact of the recent Zika epidemic in South America and Central America won't be known for several years. In the meantime, scientists face a race against time to bring the virus under control.[1] 21. 2019-present day - Named after the date when it was first identified on 31 December, 2019 in Wuhan, China, COVID-19 is a type of Coronavirus that has rapidly spread to over 210 countries and territories around the world, infecting more than 1.7 million people across the globe and killing more than 108,000 people in just 100 days with no signs of relenting and no cure. Apart from epidemics and pandemics, the world has faced many other catastrophes in history including World War I and World War II that devastated the globe, destroyed world economies and claimed the lives of an estimated 125 million people. In conclusion, I think the COVID-19 will be stopped and life will continue, albeit not without adverse economic effects. Definitely, world economies will be affected severely and may not recover from the shock any time soon. One thing is for sure — Life will never be the same again. Footnotes[1] 20 of the worst epidemics and pandemics in history

During WWI in the spring of 1918, people in port cities started dying in massive numbers due to a mysterious ailment they labeled “the blue death.” I’m referring of course to the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, the most deadly of modern times. Even with the virus being imported and exported via soldiers entering various ports throughout the world, and working their way into the countrysides across much of the populated lands, only 1/3 of the population contracted the virus, and far less actually died from it. Almost nothing was know about virology or immunology, there were no preventative or cautionary measures in place, and still the Spanish Flu came nowhere close to wiping out humanity. The CDC has now confirmed that the actual mortality rate for those who have contracted COVID-19 is ~0.2%. Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) That makes COVID-19 about as deadly as the seasonal flu. On a number of NAVY vessels, such as the USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71), over 90% of the crew tested positive for the virus and yet virtually none had any symptoms. I had COVID-19, along with almost all of my coworkers, and only two of them showed any symptoms, and only one older man with preexisting health issues actually got sick and took a few days off. The difference between the Spanish Flu pandemic and COVID-19 is that the Spanish Flu affected people in the prime of their lives, killing mostly those between 20–40 years of age. This pandemic affects mostly the elderly and those with preexisting health conditions or compromised immune systems. That said, there have been countless doctors who have come out stated that they are being pressured to list any death as a COVID death if that person had tested positive for the virus, regardless of what the actual cause of death was. For example, the only person I know who has died of COVID-19 had terminal brain cancer and a horrible case of pneumonia when they contracted the virus, and it was still listed as a COVID death. The idea that a virus could wipe out humanity is nonsensical. Even the plague aka “Black Death” only killed 1/3 of Europe’s population, and when even experts of the time were entirely ignorant of disease control and spread. There were no precautionary measures in place and modern medicine did not exist, for the most part. There’s simply no evidence to support that a virus could be an extinction event. The Spanish Flu and the Black Death didn’t exceed 1/3 of the population, in terms of infection and deaths, respectively. The greatest impact of this pandemic is the tangential aspects of the shutdown. Non-industrialized nations are experiencing famines of Biblical proportions. People are literally starving to death in greater numbers than are dying from the virus in many nations: ‘Instead of Coronavirus, the Hunger Will Kill Us.’ A Global Food Crisis Looms. And if you don’t trust the NYT: Covid-19’s Third Shock Wave: The Global Food Crisis Mental health issues like anxiety and depression have gone up 2000%. Suicide and drug overdoses have skyrocketed. The shutdown has caused a worldwide mental health crisis which no one is talking about: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/05/04/mental-health-coronavirus/ People have lost everything, and are being kept shut in a perpetual state of despair while the media keeps pumping out more and more fear—it’s what they do. A healthy person below the age of 65 has a better chance of being stuck by lightening than of dying from COVID-19. Businesses are supposed to be shutdown, unless you’re a corporation with lobbyists such as Walmart or Target, and people are supposed to be social distancing, unless it’s a protest. We were told that we don’t have the individual right to not practice social distancing because it’s not only about us, we could be killing other people’s grandparents. So either these protesters are killing a lot of grandparents and need to be stopped, or people know that the narrative is false. There is no evidence that a viral pandemic such as COVID-19 could be the end of the world, and there’s a tremendous amount of evidence to support this actually being impossible. If the Black Death nor Spanish Flu were able to take out humanity, the idea that something as deadly as the seasonal flu might is obviously nonsensical. “What It’s Like to Believe Everything the Media Tells You:”

No, not in any scenario. There are a whopping 7.5 BILLION humans, spread over virtually every square acre of land on Earth. NOTHING can reduce human population in a meaningful way, not plagues, pandemics, nuclear war, zombie apocalypses, world wars, even asteroid impacts. All that would happen is a ___% reduction in our global numbers. Say this virus infects 70% of everyone on Earth and it carries the same deadly 10% mortality rate that the Spanish Flu of 1918 had (the worst Pandemic in history). That is 10% of 70% of 7.5 billion = 525 million people dead. That is just 7% of the total world population. At our current breeding rate, we add that many babies to Earth every 5 years. By 2025, all of those dead will have been replaced and we will have set back our global population growth by just 5 years. Since humanity is the most destructive, most callous, stupidly devastating species on Earth, unable to control itself and responsible for an ongoing 6th mass extinction of other life on this beautiful planet, Earth is really doomed! As proof, in the U.S. for example, some “white supremacists” are claiming they intend to make Covid-19 into a bioterror weapon, to release onto the minority population. Ah, so sweet is Homo sapiens! Trump recently ordered that smokestack industries in the U.S. could relax their air pollution standards “due to the covid-19 crisis”. What the hell does this virus have to do with easing EPA regulations, other than a scam excuse to target EPA regulations that GOP supplicants want gone? With people like this in the world, and 40 million idiot Trump supporters believing wacko conspiracy theories and approving of this mentally ill psychopath, it is high time the human race really did go extinct. Unfortunately, that is not ever going to happen.

Let me put something into perspective. The coronavirus has killed roughly 500 people so far. Those people, of course aren’t only statistics. They were someone’s mother, father, brother, sister, friend, etc. That’s tragic, no doubt. This is a dangerous illness. However: Israeli-Gaza conflict: 1,000 deathsTōhoku earthquake and tsunami: 15,000 deathsFukushima Nuclear Power Plant disaster: 2,129 deathsWar in Iraq and Afghanistan: >182,000 deaths9–11: 2,996 deathsWorld War I: 40 million deathsWorld War II: 50–60 million deathsHiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombs: >70,000 deathsBlack Plague in Europe: 100–150 million deathsLittle Ice Age: 75 million deathsCar accidents: 1.25 million deaths/year or 3,287 deaths/dayTrain accidents: 1,000 deaths/yearEarthquakes (2010): 320,120 deathsMosquito bites: 1 million deaths/yearFlu: 12,000–61,000 deaths/yearHeart disease: 647,000 deaths/yearCancer (2018): 9.5 million deathsBut, what’s the global human population? It’s >6 billion and still growing. No, the human race isn’t going extinct. I rest my case. UPDATE: The coronavirus has now killed 30,000+ people and will likely increase from there. It has killed more people than 9–11, the Israeli-Gaza conflict, and the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant disaster combined. It’s deadlier than the flu for sure. But, just remember that I didn’t say that the coronavirus is a minor issue. It’s something that should be taken seriously as a genuine threat to your health. There’s a reason why self-quarantining, social distancing, and avoiding large crowds are the new normal for now. All I meant to say is that the coronavirus most likely isn’t going to make mankind go extinct.

This article is written for the World 🌍 What is a coronavirus?  Don’t be Panic of this Virus. It’s life span on surface is only 7 Days. This virus may not be survive direct Sunlight (die with in 2 hours on direct Sunlight) This virus can infect only 2% of human population at present status. So don’t Panic and fear of this Virus. It is not so Dangerous as you think. Coronaviruses are named for the spikes that protrude from their surfaces, resembling a crown or the sun’s corona. They can infect both animals and people, and can cause illnesses of the respiratory tract. At least four types of coronaviruses cause very mild infections every year, like the common cold. Most people get infected with one or more of these viruses at some point in their lives. How dangerous is it? It is hard to accurately assess the lethality of a new virus. It appears to be less often fatal than the coronaviruses that caused SARS or MERS, but significantly more so than the seasonal flu. The fatality rate was over 2 percent, in one study. But government scientists have estimated that the real figure could be below 1 percent, roughly the rate occurring in a severe flu season. About 5 percent of the patients who were hospitalized in China had critical illnesses. Children seem less likely to be infected with the new coronavirus, while middle-aged and older adults are disproportionately infected. Men are more likely to die from an infection compared to women, possibly because they produce weaker immune responses and have higher rates of tobacco consumption, Type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure than women, which may increase the risk of complications following an infection. “This is a pattern we’ve seen with many viral infections of the respiratory tract — men can have worse outcomes,” said Sabra Klein, a scientist who studies sex differences in viral infections and vaccination responses at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. How is the new coronavirus transmitted? Experts believe that an infected animal may have first transmitted the virus to humans at a market that sold live fish, animals and birds in Wuhan. The market was later shut down and disinfected, making it nearly impossible to investigate which animal may have been the exact origin. Bats are considered a possible source, because they have evolved to coexist with many viruses, and they were found to be the starting point for SARS. It is also possible that bats transmitted the virus to an intermediate animal, such as pangolins, which are consumed as a delicacy in parts of China, and may have then passed on the virus to humans. The outbreak grew because of human-to-human transmission. People infected with the virus produce tiny respiratory droplets when they breathe, talk, cough or sneeze, allowing the virus to travel through the air. Most respiratory droplets fall to the ground within a few feet. People who are in close contact with those infected, particularly family members and health care workers, may catch the virus this way. Infected people may be able to pass on the new coronavirus even if they have few obvious symptoms, a study in Germany has found. That’s “bad news,” said Dr. William Schaffner, an expert in infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. What symptoms should I look out for? Symptoms of this infection include fever, cough and difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. The illness causes lung lesions and pneumonia. But milder cases may resemble the flu or a bad cold, making detection difficult. Patients may exhibit other symptoms, too, such as gastrointestinal problems or diarrhea. Current estimates suggest that symptoms may appear in as few as two days or as long as 14 days after being exposed to the virus. If you have a fever or a cough and recently visited China, South Korea, Italy or another place with a known coronavirus outbreak, or spent time with someone who did, see your health care provider. Call first, so the office can prepare for your visit and take steps to protect other patients and staff from potential exposure. Is there a test for the virus? What is the treatment? There is a diagnostic test that can determine if you are infected. It was developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, based on genetic information about the virus provided by the Chinese authorities. In early February, the C.D.C. sent diagnostic test kits to 200 state laboratories, but some of the kits were flawed and recalled. Now other laboratories are making their own tests. Other countries are using test kits manufactured locally or sent out by the W.H.O. The C.D.C. announced that anyone who wanted to be tested could if a doctor approves the request. But state and local health departments, already overwhelmed with requests, must conduct the tests, not the individual doctors. Many patients complain that they still cannot get tested. How can I protect myself? The best thing you can do to avoid getting infected is to follow the same general guidelines that experts recommend during flu season, because the coronavirus spreads in much the same way. Wash your hands frequentlythroughout the day. Avoid touching your face, and maintain a distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing. At the moment, the risk of infection with the new coronavirus in the United States “is way too low for the general public to start wearing a face mask,” said Dr. Peter Rabinowitz, co-director of the University of Washington MetaCenter for Pandemic Preparedness and Global Health Security. But, he added, “if you have symptoms of a respiratory illness, wearing a mask reduces the risk of infecting others.” Should I cancel my international travel plans? The C.D.C. has warned Americans not to travel to China or South Korea unless it is absolutely essential. The State Department on Sunday warned Americans not to travel on cruise ships at all. Older adults and people with chronic medical conditions should also consider postponing travel anywhere, particularly by air, federal officials warned. Many countries have also enacted travel restrictions and bans, closing their doors to people from countries with sustained transmission of the virus. Governments around the world have been screening incoming passengers for signs of illness. Thailand and Malaysia have turned away yet another cruise ship, this one carrying a large number of Italians. Airlines and cruise lines have canceled service to destinations affected by the outbreak, with others, including United Airlines, cutting back on domestic service and international service. Is it too late to contain the virus? W.H.O. officials have credited lockdown measures China imposed in late January for averting the spread of more cases from Wuhan. China sealed off cities, shut down businesses and schools, and ordered residents to remain in their homes. Officials use cellphone data to track and intercept those who have been to Hubei Province. In recent weeks, government workers have gone door-to-door to round up people who are infected, placing them in stadiums and other buildings that have been converted to makeshift hospitals. Now, official reports suggest that new cases in China are waning. But there is growing fear that containment may no longer be possible. Clarence Tam, an assistant professor of infectious diseases at the School of Public Health at the National University of Singapore, said the surge of cases in multiple countries was “concerning because we know the transmissions are spreading at a fast rate.” “We’ve learned some things of this new virus for the past couple of weeks that make it seem unlikely that containment will be a strategy that will completely stop this virus,” he added. There is benefit to delaying its spread as long as possible. Containing the virus may buy health officials more time to stock hospitals with test kits and respirators, and develop drugs for treatment and a vaccine. But the ability of nations to prepare for the arrival of coronavirus cases will depend largely on the strength of their health systems, capacity to conduct tests and effectiveness in communicating updates to the public. “We have been dealing with flu for decades, and even now it seems some countries don’t even have a policy for influenza preparedness,” said Leo Poon, head of the University of Hong Kong’s public health laboratory sciences division. “Not to mention something which is new to them. That’s a problem.”

I keep seeing the ‘flu’ analogy, It has been a bad flu season, true. And it is a good thing to say to not upset people. COVID 19 is not a flu, it’s a Coronavirus, the 2 Coronavirus outbreaks in the last 20 years were the SAR’s CoV, and the MER’s CoV, they had the nasty habit of killing, respectively, 14% of those infected and 34% infected. RACGP - How does coronavirus compare with previous global outbreaks? Luckily, COVID - 19 is pretty anaemic compared to that. It’s still worse than flu. People keep quoting a 2% death rate and saying “yeah, but the flu kills more”. No, the flu kills about 0.1%, but more people have had it - So more have died, simple as that. At COVID-19’s 2% or the sometimes mentioned 2.3% thats 20 or 23 times worse than the flu. 20 times more fatal is deadly (excuse the pun) serious. Even worse, if it can be worse, is that around 20% - not 2%, 20% are ending up with pneumonia or in ICU. That is awful with a capital ‘A’. Awful in my country, with free medical care, ruinous in the US, unless your insurance covers it. I note stats currently show 78,994 cases, 2,470 dead and 23,419 recovered. That leaves over 50,000 still to get well, but they hopefully end up in the recovered category. If these stats are true this one has “ahh, f##k…” written all over it -. They may not be true however… It is possible we are only seeing the fin of the shark and there are large numbers of people catching this who are not showing up in the statistics. Someone catches a sniffle, spreads it to mum, dad, and the lady at the pie shop, who also catch a sniffle. We only notice it later when a couple of people down the road get really sick and they only get counted in the statistics. That could skew the death rate back towards the ‘bad flu’ rate. Currently however, we don’t have enough evidence to prove that. It would also make it very hard to stop, as almost symptomless people can still spread it. As strange as it seems we really have no idea how bad this is going to get or how far it is going to spread. This illness is only 2 months old. We still have a lot to learn.

I have done battle with this virus before. Despite the talk and the fact that virus may be mutated etc I would like to explain how to fight it. It can be easily defeated. Wash your hands a lotClean up your toilet facilitiesIf a significant level of infection is happening around your area, get your building plumbing inspected and repaired.I know that seems to simple but the last time this virus stuck it’s head up that killed it. You don’t have that much of a problem as you might think. We can defeat this by simple measures. Yes I was the one who wrote the report to the US-CIA on how to defeat this disease the last time and it worked. Now unless you think this is funny, this is standard medical stuff and standard epidemiology. If you want to live and do well get everyone doing this stuff. No virus will kill out everyone. People will survive. The sci fi terror of a lethal germ that kills everyone isn’t what happens. Actually the morality and morbidity and incubation times for this virus are close to as bad as it gets. More than likely this disease going to be coldcocked about as fast as it appears. We know how to fight it. Just everyone get with the program and it will go away. This disease has a definite racial variant and it attacks Chinese people more than others. That doesn’t mean it will not bother others. The last time it appeared it was associated with failed plumbing systems of large high rise buildings in about 12 buildings. The location and conditions of this emergence look the same. There may be variations we do not know at this time. The trigger for this outbreak is most probably some major event or condition that has developed in the past year where a lot of people moved in or out of the area of Wuhan China. I would suggest it is likely to be related to Chinese Military movements as such diseases typically associate so. But I do not know for sure. It could be some civilian movements or event. Is the Chinese Communist Party being on the up and up on this? Probably not but this will sort itself out in time. The measures to control the epidemic are not different regardless. China has much issues with public health and safety that are not resolved and with it’s high population that makes thes much worse for the world and much more dangerous.

Simple answer; probably not. If you are worried about global recession, here are some basic principals; there will probably be a large reduction in output in the developed world because we have such a large service/leisure based economy. In the developing world, manufacturing is the main basis of it’s output, and they supply us with many of the “things” we buy. This means as long as we buy electronics, plastic products, coffee, sugar, fuel etc. the developing nations will export things to us, and they will keep going, financially, just as before. when the infection levels fall away in the developed nations we will go back to traveling the world, enjoying leisure activities, going to bars/restaurants/hotels/clubs/cinema’s etc. and the world will be “normal” again. As far as the G20 nations, there will be short term declines in living standards, but fiscal protection packages and consumer markets are strong in these regions. Government policies will inherently protect most major employers, and once the virus runs through it’s growth phase, these employers and industries will re-ignite the economy. We will probably see a boom in the service sector and employment rates will jump. Don’t forget, most food retail, agricultural/farming, manufacturing, supply chain/logistics/freight, financial, and state agencies are all still in operation. This means that many people who have/will lose work( specifically those in the service industry, like bars, leisure, hotels and restaurants, or the gig economy((not food delivery!)) will have jobs to go back to after the infection rates fall and the service industry starts up again. National governments in the G20 are also introducing packages intended to sustain those businesses while they are forced into closure, and the G7 nations are all looking at personal relief packages(short term universal income!). Maybe we can learn from it, hygiene for one! Washing hands is very effective at slowing/stopping almost all disease spread. so that would be a good behavioural change. I don’t think Covid-19 will ruin the world, it has and will ruin a lot of lives, it will change it in many ways. Short term changes and impacts through restrictions aimed at limiting the virus’s effects will affect us. But long term? Things will be back to how they were, sorrow for the dead, maybe a few memorials will be built, and our leaders will say some words and make promises as usual. In one year’s time, we probably won’t see much change from how it was in 2019, 2020 will be looked back on like 2016, bad stuff and changes happened and we moved on.

Not even remotely close. Even in the absolute worst-case scenario where the disease is maliciously killing its hosts on purpose (which isn’t a thing), there’s no such thing as a plague that kills 100% of the people it infects. The reason for this is genetic diversity. Or more accurately, sexual reproduction (as opposed to asexual reproduction like cloning of plants or cell division among bacteria) creates such diversity that no one cause can wipe out a species, which has enabled such species to flourish and produce as many different variations as we see today. This is a feature of human beings going back so far in our genetic history, that it was a feature from back before when we were fish. As a result, by default, some percentage of us are naturally immune to Coronavirus and any other virus that might kill us as well. That percentage is quite high, as is demonstrated by this statistic: 80 people are dead and more than 2,700 cases have been confirmed in mainland China Ref: Coronavirus outbreak: Latest news and live updates - CNN This means that so far (with modern medicine helping us out), only 2.9% of the people with enough symptoms to not just shrug it off as a case of the sniffles, have died, leaving 97.1% of those able to survive so far. Even if the death toll were to triple as the disease runs its course, that would still mean only 8.9% would die, leaving behind 91.1% of the population, in the absolute worst case scenario. I’m not even counting the number of people who have been exposed to the virus and absolutely nothing has happened at all. I’m making a big, fat assumption that 100% of the population is going to be infected. Just think about how Wuhan has a population of 11 million people, and only 2700 of them have gotten sick so far. Don’t fall for the hype and the psychotic intentions of politicians who would like to say there’s a boogeyman over yonder hill coming to gobble us all up if we don’t kill them all now (or whatever they intend to do with that kind of fear). It’s a story as old as the first politician.

No. If it does become a full-blown pandemic - at ~25% global infection (1918 level) and <5% mortality (which is more aggressive than what we’ve seen so far, and final numbers tend towards the less aggressive), tens of millions will be dead. Perhaps even a hundred million. And while this may sound heartless, it isn’t an extinction, it’s a culling. Even if it targeted the reproductive-age population (like 1918), it still couldn’t cause extinction. Humanity will be fine. The biggest challenge will be dealing with the economic effects of population loss (like reduced demand), although again not to sound heartless, many countries could end up “in the black” on that point by saving spending on their retirement systems. [Ed: An explanation on the economics…] Those most affected by COVID are elderly, thus most likely to be retired and non-working. On the federal balance sheet, they represent a large liability in the form of SS and Medicare spending. On state balance sheets, they represent a lot of public pensioners and consume a lot of public services. Macroeconomically, they don’t produce much supply, and where they do, they mostly undercut youth wages by competing for employment with them (like the seniors working at McDonalds). They DO produce a lot of demand, however, in the form of health care. Home care, hospice, all the various ailments of old age, etc. They also have a lot of savings. A massive die-off of 2.3 million Americans, probably at least 2 million of whom will be seniors, would (1) relieve the government of their entitlement liabilities, (2) negligibly reduce supply, (3) temporarily spike demand for elderly health services, then settle into a permanent reduction of demand, and (4) transfer a lot of wealth to younger generations. Again, this is not intended to paint a cheerful picture. My own grandmother definitely falls into this at-risk category, and I’d hate to lose her to this crisis - I thought we had at least a FEW more years left. I’m just trying to present some cold hard facts about how it would impact the global economy. We’ve already seen the negative effects just from the containment effort and the stock- and oil-market fallouts. I’m just pointing out that there are some inherent aspects to the way the disease might kill people and who it kills and what they mean to the economy, which would spur the eventual recovery.

Answered 18 June 2020: Added 2 September 2020: A recent hypothesis developed with help by artificial intelligence suggests that the virus may be hemorrhagic. It’s called the Bradykinin hypothesis. Added 4 July 2020: Evidence for immunity has emerged in infected Chinese monkeys. China announced a vaccine on June 25 and is inoculating members of their military. China agreed on July 2 to partner with Brazil to test another version of a coronavirus vaccine they have in their arsenal. —————————————— Until there is evidence for acquired immunity, the emergence of this virus in humans has to be treated as a species-extinction event. Why? It’s high transmissibility and lethality makes a population collapse inevitable absent an effective vaccine. If humans prove unable to acquire immunity, a vaccine cannot be made even in principle. The apparent ease with which this virus jumps species is worrisome. Passing the virus back and forth between humans and their animals makes contact tracing difficult to impossible. It adds a level of complexity to the problem that we don’t need right now. Animal transmission means that a reduction in the target population of humans will not necessarily reduce their exposure to the virus, because virus transmission to humans from asymptomatic animal populations can drive the virus into remote concentrations of human survivors. Is the coronavirus going to end the world? It is impossible to predict the future effects of the coronavirus on this planet of 7.7 billion humans. The virus, called SARS-CoV-2, made its first public appearance in a seafood-and-live-animal market in Wuhan, China in January 2020. Since then, as the number of COVID-19 cases confirmed overseas daily have surpassed those within China, the draconian measures that appear to have quelled the outbreak domestically are gradually being relaxed. Experts say one possibility is that cases of the disease will start decreasing when enough people develop immunity, either through infection or vaccination. Another possible scenario is that the virus will continue to circulate and establish itself as a common respiratory virus. Pandemics end when the virus doesn't have enough susceptible people to infect. The catastrophic 1918 Spanish flu pandemic is thought to have infected 500 million people worldwide, many of them soldiers living in close quarters fighting in World War I. Once the war ended and people dispersed, the spread slowed as people had less contact. But the flu was ultimately halted in part because those who survived it had immunity and the virus didn't hop as easily as it did at the beginning. If the virus comes into contact with another person but that person isn't susceptible to the disease, then that chain of transmission is snuffed out. If one person infects two, those people together infect four and so on, and eventually, the virus runs out of susceptible people to infect. Another possibility is that SARS-CoV-2 will mutate in a potentially beneficial way, making it more difficult for the virus to infect people. Back in 2002, a similar coronavirus in the Guangdong province of southern China first hopped to humans from animals and caused an outbreak of an infection that became known as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The virus that caused SARS had a relatively low mutation rate, so it didn't reoccur. In the end, it is impossible to predict how the virus will behave. With the massive population and continual contact with animal reservoirs, new viruses will keep emerging.

Coronavirus Coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). A novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans. Coronaviruses are zoonotic, meaning they are transmitted between animals and people. Detailed investigations found that SARS-CoV was transmitted from civet cats to humans and MERS-CoV from dromedary camels to humans. Several known coronaviruses are circulating in animals that have not yet infected humans. Common signs of infection include respiratory symptoms, fever, cough, shortness of breath and breathing difficulties. In more severe cases, infection can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death. Standard recommendations to prevent infection spread include regular hand washing, covering mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing, thoroughly cooking meat and eggs. Avoid close contact with anyone showing symptoms of respiratory illness such as coughing and sneezing. No, not even close. Coronavirus (Covid-19) will kill some (it already has), though it's nowhere near fatal enough to kill the “entire world”. Data from Germany suggests the fatality rate is around 0.4%, and the UK government is reporting 1 death per 1,000 infected (i.e. - a fatality rate of just 0.1%). And note that the vast majority of deaths are coming from those age 65+, and those with certain pre-existing health conditions (often an overlap of both categories). Note that the official/confirmed fatality rates you are seeing, on say Worldometers, or official government sites, are coming out far higher than these fatality rates - simply because every fatality is being accounted for, but only a small proportion of cases are (i.e. - making it look more fatal than it is, and at the same time significantly undercounting the true number of infected). This is because, in the UK for example, the only people being tested for Covid-19, are a portion of those being hospitalised with suspected symptoms (i.e. - only the most severe cases are being tested for). Meanwhile, there are many people out there with Covid-19, who are either asymptomatic, or have mild symptoms, and therefore aren't being tested, so aren't forming part of this data. It's important to note, the world's population is higher than its ever been before (estimated @ 7.8 billion people), so that could have the effect of making Covid-19 look worse than it really is (when comparing to historic pandemics), since there's now a bigger pool of people to infect & kill then there ever has been. Hence why it's better to look at the proportion of people alive that died, rather than just the absolute number.

There are two ways we can look at what impact the new coronavirus has on the world 1. Mortality rate: Latest WHO estimates put the mortality rate at 3.4%. Now while this might seem like a lot, compared to other viruses like SARS (9.6%) or MERS (34%), it is quite low. The main problem is the high rate at which it spreads, which is also the reason why it managed to kill more people than SARS in such a short time. It is also important to consider what kind of people contribute the most to the death toll: if you contract the virus and are under 50, the chance of dying is under 0.4%. The numbers increase drastically the higher we look at the age. People between 70–79 have an 8% chance of dying, while people over 80 have a 14.8% chance of dying. Pre-existing medical conditions also play a huge role, changing the mortality rate by 5 to 10% depending on the disease. COVID-19 might not destory the world by killing off all it’s inhabitants, but there is another way it can affect society… 2. Economy: And I am not only talking about hand sanitizers and face masks. While fearmongering and panic caused virus protection products to spike in sales (and also skyrocket in price), other areas of the economy are suffering right now: in Europe, among other sectors, oil and gas stocks fell by over 16%. Italy’s FTSE MIB fell by 11%, Germany’s DAX by 8% and France’s CAC 40 by 8.4%. For those unfamiliar with the stock market (like myself a couple of moments ago), these changes are quite the contrary of good. And it does not only affect the stock market; new prevention laws in Italy and Germany are prohibiting gatherings of over 1,000 people (including festivals, concerts, conventions, and other events), while Italy went a step further and also closed down schools, museums, cinemas, theatres, night clubs, sport events… the list goes on. While it is only for a short time, this means huge losses for the economy. Having families under quarantine also means that those people can not be productive, which further increases economic strain. So could the coronavirus destroy the world by ruining the economy? Probably not. While it does certainly slow it down, people do recover from the virus. In fact, people have already recovered from over half of the coronavirus cases recorded to this date. On the bright side though, the virus did have a positive impact on the environment, quite contrary to destroying the world. Please read the actual article with in-depth information on the Coronavirus: Coronavirus: what happens to people's lungs when they get Covid-19? Respiratory physician John Wilson explains the range of Covid-19 impacts, from no symptoms to severe illness featuring pneumonia Follow our Australian coronavirus live blog the latest local updatesFollow the global coronavirus blog for live news and latest updatesGraham Readfearn @readfearn Email Thu 12 Mar 2020 16.30 GMT Last modified on Sat 14 Mar 2020 05.07 GMT  What became known as Covid-19, or the coronavirus, started in late 2019 and early 2020 in the Chinese city of Wuhan as a cluster of pneumonia cases with an unknown cause. The cause of the pneumonia was found to be a new virus – severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or Sars-CoV-2. The illness caused by the virus is Covid-19. Now declared as a pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO), the majority of people who contract Covid-19 suffer only mild, cold-like symptoms. ‘He’s gonna get us all killed’: sense of unease after Trump coronavirus speech Read more WHO says about 80% of people with Covid-19 recover without needing any specialist treatment. Only about one person in six becomes seriously ill “and develops difficulty breathing”. So how can Covid-19 develop into a more serious illness featuring pneumonia, and what does that do to our lungs and the rest of our body? How is the virus affecting people? Guardian Australia spoke with Prof John Wilson, president-elect of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and a respiratory physician. He says almost all serious consequences of Covid-19 feature pneumonia.  The coronavirus outbreak started in Wuhan as a cluster of pneumonia cases with an unknown cause. Photograph: Barcroft Media via Getty Images Wilson says people who catch Covid-19 can be placed into four broad categories. The least serious are those people who are “sub-clinical” and who have the virus but have no symptoms. Next are those who get an infection in the upper respiratory tract, which, Wilson says, “means a person has a fever and a cough and maybe milder symptoms like headache or conjunctivitis”. He says: “Those people with minor symptoms are still able to transmit the virus but may not be aware of it.” Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson's travels: selfies, shows and beachside strolls before coronavirus diagnosis Read more The largest group of those who would be positive for Covid-19, and the people most likely to present to hospitals and surgeries, are those who develop the same flu-like symptoms that would usually keep them off work. A fourth group, Wilson says, will develop severe illness that features pneumonia. He says: “In Wuhan, it worked out that from those who had tested positive and had sought medical help, roughly 6% had a severe illness.” The WHO says the elderly and people with underlying problems like high blood pressure, heart and lung problems or diabetes, are more likely to develop serious illness. Professor Robert Booy from the University of Sydney, Head of Clinical Research at the National Centre for Immunisation Research and Surveillance, answers questions about what Covid-19 does to the body. How does the pneumonia develop? When people with Covid-19 develop a cough and fever, Wilson says this is a result of the infection reaching the respiratory tree – the air passages that conduct air between the lungs and the outside. He says: “The lining of the respiratory tree becomes injured, causing inflammation. This in turn irritates the nerves in the lining of the airway. Just a speck of dust can stimulate a cough. “But if this gets worse, it goes past just the lining of the airway and goes to the gas exchange units, which are at the end of the air passages. “If they become infected they respond by pouring out inflammatory material into the air sacs that are at the bottom of our lungs.” If the air sacs then become inflamed, Wilson says this causes an “outpouring of inflammatory material [fluid and inflammatory cells] into the lungs and we end up with pneumonia.” He says lungs that become filled with inflammatory material are unable to get enough oxygen to the bloodstream, reducing the body’s ability to take on oxygen and get rid of carbon dioxide. “That’s the usual cause of death with severe pneumonia,” he says. How can the pneumonia be treated? Prof Christine Jenkins, chair of Lung Foundation Australia and a leading respiratory physician, told Guardian Australia: “Unfortunately, so far we don’t have anything that can stop people getting Covid-19 pneumonia. “People are already trialling all sorts of medications and we’re hopeful that we might discover that there are various combinations of viral and anti-viral medications that could be effective. At the moment there isn’t any established treatment apart from supportive treatment, which is what we give people in intensive care. “We ventilate them and maintain high oxygen levels until their lungs are able to function in a normal way again as they recover.” Coronavirus Australia: Labor calls for mass events to be cancelled and schools closed Read more Wilson says patients with viral pneumonia are also at risk of developing secondary infections, so they would also be treated with anti-viral medication and antibiotics. “In some situations that isn’t enough,” he says of the current outbreak. “The pneumonia went unabated and the patients did not survive.” Is Covid-19 pneumonia different? Jenkins says Covid-19 pneumonia is different from the most common cases that people are admitted to hospitals for. “Most types of pneumonia that we know of and that we admit people to hospital for are bacterial and they respond to an antibiotic. Wilson says there is evidence that pneumonia caused by Covid-19 may be particularly severe. Wilson says cases of coronavirus pneumonia tend to affect all of the lungs, instead of just small parts. He says: “Once we have an infection in the lung and, if it involves the air sacs, then the body’s response is first to try and destroy [the virus] and limit its replication.” But Wilson says this “first responder mechanism” can be impaired in some groups, including people with underlying heart and lung conditions, diabetes and the elderly. Jenkins says that, generally, people aged 65 and over are at risk of getting pneumonia, as well as people with medical conditions such as diabetes, cancer or a chronic disease affecting the lungs, heart, kidney or liver, smokers, Indigenous Australians, and infants aged 12 months and under. “Age is the major predictor of risk of death from pneumonia. Pneumonia is always serious for an older person and in fact it used to be one of the main causes of death in the elderly. Now we have very good treatments for pneumonia. “It’s important to remember that no matter how healthy and active you are, your risk for getting pneumonia increases with age. This is because our immune system naturally weakens with age, making it harder for our bodies to fight off infections and diseases.”

The current increase in number of cases in the US actually tracks with the increase in cases in China several months ago during the initial outbreak. Most importantly, the current number of reported cases in China is in decline. So there’s no reason to suspect the same won’t happen in the US, even more quickly, and that it won’t reach anywhere near the levels in China, where they were initially slow to respond and made no attempt to isolate infected people in the Wuhan and Hubei Provences where it started. Outside those areas (in China) cases are much lower. Comparisons to the Spanish Flu pandemic made by your typically irresponsible reporters and tv hosts (Bill Maher) are poor comparisons, mainly because that was an era before antibiotics. The better comparison apparently (according to the CDC) is with SARS. Quoting from a report: China began clinical trials of a SARS vaccine in November 2003, while in the US, the first human SARS trials began in December 2004, conducted by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases….Harvard professor Wayne Marasco identified a single antibody out of a 27-billion antibody library that blocked the SARS virus from entering human cells. Marasco is actively testing new antibodies in search of one that will have the same effect on SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) There’s no reason to assume the Corona virus won’t be contained and won’t soon be in decline (as it is in China) and I’m sure these are some of the factors behind Trump’s typical glass half full demeanor. Finally, in addition to all the above consider this info from a J P Morgan analysis: During the haze of a pandemic, the best estimates that entities like the World Health Organization often derive are … complicated by [the affecting of] older individuals with pre-existing conditions. They do not know [the total number of infected individuals, including both asymptomatic people and people that get sick] … and sometimes it is never known, or only known with the passage of time. Take the Swine Flu (H1N1/2009) as an example. Early estimates in the fall of 2009 from the WHO1 pegged the H1N1 mortality rate at 1.0%-1.3%…. Four years later [their] revised H1N1 mortality rate: just 0.02%. [Regarding the current Corona outbreak:] The vast majority of infected people will likely not become sick, and around 80% of people who get sick develop mild infections rather than severe ones. So yes, I think the world is safe. — Main source: J P Morgan analyst Michael Cembalest, March 9th, 2020.

It is not the flu. That being said it is an upper resperatory infection and flu is the closest thing that most people are personally familiar with. It is more closely related to some of the cold viruses but in severity and presentation more flu-like due to fever being a common symptom. “just” the flu can and has killed large numbers of people. The 1918 Spanish Flu Killed 50–100 Million people. There is nothing “just” about the flu but the Novel Coronavirus isn’t a flu. It is a new strain and it is highly infectious as well as having a reported high percentage of those infected dying from it. The big problem is that people appear to be infectious BEFORE onset of symptoms. No one has ever had this strain before so no one has specific anitbodies against it. I’ve seen people say no one is immune but I haven’t seen anything saying that exposure 100% leads to testing positive with or without symptoms. It has the potential to hit everyone in a community at the same time. No country has the resources to deal with that. It leads to pneumonia in 20% of the cases. Apparently it takes a while for some people to get over it as in weeks and well potentially months. The REALLY scary part is it mutated to this brand new strain and it could mutate into even more deadly strains. We don’t know how to treat it (except treat the symptoms), we don’t know how many people will get it. For every person with the illness you have to have others to support and care for them. The wartime analogy is for every wounded soldier you take 3 out of service. For every dead soldier you only took out 1. Our infrastructure (any country) isn’t set up for that with already dealing with an aging population. I am still personally more concerned about the flu (not this years strain) in general than this new corona virus but I could see where this could easily change as we learn more. In the USA even Fast Tracked an FDA approved vaccine would take 6 months once they have developed it to be available.

No. There are those that are immune to the virus. Here is what has recently been published concerning COV-id 19 What is the Coronavirus: There are many different strains of the coronavirus. Most are not deadly and only cause illnesses like the common cold. Human coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that can cause a variety of illnesses ranging from the common cold to severe diseases like Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV). The World Health Organization says Novel Coronavirus (nCoV) is a new strain that had not been previously identified in humans until late 2019. How did it originate: A new study published in the peer-reviewed journal Antiviral Research (Vol. 16, April 2020) is entitled, “The spike glycoprotein of the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV contains a furin-like cleavage site absent in CoV of the same clade.” It reveals that the CoVid-19 coronavirus contains unique features that allow it to function as a more efficient weapon system for human-to-human transmission, which helps explain why the virus has been impossible to contain (even under “quarantine” conditions, which have universally failed in China, Japan, Korea and elsewhere). As the science authors of the paper explain in the full text, “This furin-like cleavage site… may provide a gain-of-function to the 2019-nCoV for efficient spreading in the human population.” (Emphasis added) Further, the science paper finds that there is no known viral ancestry to the CoVid-19 coronavirus, meaning it did not evolve from nature. It was engineered, and the science paper authors also state that the virus contains elements from MERS, stating, “Before the emergence of the 2019-nCoV, this important feature was not observed in the lineage b of beta coronaviruses.” The abstract and full PDF (paid) of the study is available through this link at Science, health and medical journals, full text articles and books.: The spike glycoprotein of the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV contains a furin-like cleavage site absent in CoV of the same clade

Good grief, no! COVID-19’s ability as an infective agent is still the subject of some debate, with some giving the virus a reproductive rate lower than influenza, others considering it more able to reproduce than mumps, and most giving it a reproductive rate roughly equivalent to HIV. In crude terms, everyone with COVID-19 has the potential to pass it on to somewhere between two and three people before the host either quarantines themselves or becomes too ill to viably continue spreading the virus. However, even at that alarming rate the chances of it infecting a significant proportion of society is low. Only the measles (which has a reproductive rate of around 18) managed to infect most people before vaccination stopped its horrors. If we think it like other respiratory diseases spread by droplet infection, it could infect anything between a quarter and a half of the population of the planet. It’s fatality rate is also the subject of some debate, but presently stands between 0.7% and 4% of the infected population. That figure could rise slightly if it overstretches health services around the world, but possibly not as much as you might think. Absolute worst case scenario: it kills 120m people. While that would make it seem worse than the 1919 flu (which killed as much as 100m worldwide), as a percentage of the population, the 1919 flu was more devastating (there are 7.7bn alive today, there was about 1.9bn alive then). We survived the 1919 flu, we’ll survive this. It might change society, especially as it seems to be particularly damaging to the older parts of society. But not destroy it. And the likelihood is the disease will kill far fewer people, because as its impact begins to hit, people naturally isolate themselves as much as possible, limiting transmission. Eventually it either burns out or mutates and returns in greater or weaker strength every few years.

The world itself is not vulnerable to disease, so no to that.  Could disease end the human race? Technically, yes, though it would need very different properties than coronaviruses have. Anthrax spores live essentially indefinitely in the environment, while coronavirus dies in hours, days at most. So, a virus or bacterium that survives a very long time would be good.Being very infectious (not merely contagious) would be ideal. Coronavirus is pretty good at this, but being able to also be spread by wind like the dust from the Sahara would be better.Having a long “asymptomatic carrier” period would also help, where people are walking around and spreading it without knowing.And then being rapidly and absolutely fatal to humans would be necessary, to wipe out humanity. If someone caught it, they might be walking around for a month, but after that incubation time, a quick death. Coronavirus is only maybe 5% fatal in humans, maybe a little more.Mutating rapidly.So you’d end up with a disease as omnipresent as mold spores, which all humans and animals can spread to other humans, and which kills them dead. Even if people shelter in place for years, they eventually must come out, and will die. A single breach of any shelter would be all it’d take. So, yes, humanity could be wiped out by a pandemic. Unless we first make it to another planet. In that case, the incubation period would need to be longer than the travel time to the other planet. HOWEVER. If push came to shove, we could genetically engineer humanity to be immune to any (or even all) viruses. It would be a monumental engineering task, but people have already started this task in animals, editing their genes to simply not use certain sequences that all viruses require, and instead replacing them with “synonymous” ones. So, we might all die, but if we had time, we might just be able to raise a new generation of children who would live.

I remember the 2012 End-of-the-world panic, when people actually believed that this could be it for the planet. Hoarding up supplies, spreading misinformation, preparing for doomsday were some of the many outright insane things that humanity resorted to. WHO has declared the COVID-19 a global pandemic, and has asserted the need for rigorous actions in 100+ affected countries. The concerns and gloom surrounding the pandemic are valid, but misinformation coupled with panic is travelling faster than a supersonic jet. Is there a silver lining though? Most people infected with the virus recover. The infection could be fatal in people of the older age group, with comorbidities or pre-existing health conditions. Every viral outbreak takes a course of 8-10 weeks before the peak dies down. China is already on its road to recovery. Moreover, researchers are working hard to develop medicines and vaccines to alleviate the setback. Vaccine trials are already underway for testing and it may take 6 more weeks until it is put to use for the general public.The environment is cleaner and the air is getting less toxic with the reduction of traffic and public gatherings amidst the lockdown. That is something to look forward to- and we must allow nature to have its break, especially in this era of rapid climate change.What can you do to help? It is important that you avoid or reschedule your travel plans, as you are not only doing yourself a favour by steering clear from potential risks, but you are also being an impactful helping hand in containing the virus. Although a younger person can survive the infection, it is important to make sure it is not passed on to vulnerable individuals who may not survive it.Practice hand hygiene and respiratory hygiene adequately. Avoid smoking, wash hands regularly and always wear a mask if you have a cough or are feeling sick. Be mindful of your surroundings, avoid shaking hands and keep one metre’s distance from anybody who has cough, fever or breathing difficulty, but politely.Protect yourself and your near and dear ones first, and in case you suspect that you may have the infection, please make sure you postpone any social interactions and gatherings. Impose a self-quarantine for the safety of others, and contact the helpline number that has been set up for various states across the country (Central line for more information in India: +91-11-23978046).

We will understand how great the generosity of the other countries can be, that often our friend could be farther than those we believe to be close and that could be just what we had discriminated against until recently. We will understand that Brexit could have condemned the United Kingdom to face an unprecedented crisis with its own strength and that perhaps, in the not too distant future, it will be necessary to ask for help precisely to those of whom it took at all costs get rid of it. We will understand that only through the cooperation of all political forces can important decisions be made and we will understand how much we must “remain united” in such difficult moments, beyond our ideals. No. There is no end of the world. Matter continually changes and upgrades, never dying. The coronavirus, as well as other epidemics, natural disasters, and literally any form that appears negative toward us from nature, surfaces in order to ultimately bring us closer to nature. We might think that it is absurd, because how could a problem that kills and makes so many people sick bring us closer to nature?  Photo by 🇨🇭 Claudio Schwarz | @purzlbaum on Unsplash Nature is an interconnected and interdependent system that relates to all of its parts—the still, vegetative, animate and human—as a single whole. It does not relate to our physical bodies, but to what makes us human: our attitudes to each other. Letting our attitudes to each other remain egoistic and self-centered, focused only on benefiting ourselves at the expense of other people and nature, awakens a negative response from nature. Blows from nature come ultimately in order to wake us up to the need to change our egoistic attitude to an attitude that is balanced with nature. If we relate to nature’s feedback—seemingly negative phenomena as the coronavirus and myriad other blows that we endure—as a complete interconnected and interdependent system wanting and trying to bring us into balance with itself, then our correct response would be to merge our attitudes to each other in order to match nature’s integrality. In other words, our correct response to blows from nature, especially the coronavirus, is to seek how we can better relate to one another, in order to become more unified and reach balance with nature. Therefore, especially while we are under social distancing conditions brought upon us with the coronavirus, we would use these conditions ideally if we undertook a self-scrutiny, to reach the realization of how the coronavirus crisis came to us as a response to our imbalance with nature, and also to seek how we could use the time when we are isolated from each other in order to become more united and balanced with nature.

No Way - There’s already evidence that Kaletra (or any generic Lopinavir/Ritonavir) is curing this virus in 48hrs or so. “HIV drugs, like lopinavir (ritonavir is mixed in to delay the breakdown of lopinavir in the body so that it has time to make its way to the infected cells), binds to certain protease enzymes that are typically encoded in viral genetic material. These proteases are required to "chop" up the long virus proteins that are generated when they hijack a cell's machinery to make copies of themselves. These chopped up protein segments are assembled to create copies of the virus. The HIV drug binds to the protease enzyme to inhibit its function, which subsequently inhibits the virus's ability to assemble copies of itself.” [1] source: Kaletra antiretroviral test against Covid-19 in South Korea Flu and HIV Drugs Show Efficacy Against Coronavirus Doctors fight coronavirus outbreak with drugs that target HIV, malaria and Ebola China Names HIV Drugs in Treatment Plan for New Virus China repurposes AbbVie HIV drug as Big Pharma rallies to combat deadly coronavirus Footnotes[1] Thailand 'cures' coronavirus with anti-HIV drug cocktail in 48 hours...The doctors combined the anti-flu drug oseltamivir with lopinavir and ritonavir, anti-virals used to treat HIV

No. Not at all. It’s not nearly deadly enough. But the worst case scenario is still pretty rough. It is relatively benign compared to close relatives SARS and MERS (if still worse than the flu). The usual mechanism that keeps viruses like Ebola in check, extreme virulence, doesn’t come into play here, so carriers with few or no symptoms can get to all parts of the world, silently transmit the virus, clear the virus from their systems uneventfully, and never even realize they were infected. There is no danger of this putting the world population as a whole in any real jeopardy, but it’s still enough to potentially create a great big mess. Thus far, the people that do have something to worry about are the immunocompromised — elders, young children, HIV+ people. And it very well might turn into a complete shitshow for the medical community. But for most of us, it’ll probably be okay in the end.

If a disease is 100% fatal, that limits the spread. Anything that virulent is likely to make you really ill, so you're bedridden and not interacting with others and spreading the disease. From an evolutionary perspective, a relatively mild disease is the more fit to survive, long-term. The really big epidemics in history swept through, killed lots of highly susceptible people, and usually vanished as quickly as they'd arrived. Plus, mankind has enough knowledge to create medicines and vaccines to treat or stop the illness. This is a relatively recent phenomenon in our history. And if a 100% fatal epidemic were sweeping the planet, you're guaranteed to have relatively self- sufficient islands in the South Pacific and pockets in rural areas of the major continents that would seal themselves off from the rest of the world. No contact with contaminated people = no epidemic.

No. No more than the H1N1 scare or Bird Flu panic. And let’s put it in perspective. The reason we’re terrified of the flu is because of the 1918 flu pandemic. It arrived as a war ended, millions of refugees on the move and then soldiers coming home. Depending on the source, it either killed as many people as World War 1 or twice as many. (Do you count people with TB who died of the flu? Do they count any death of respiratory illness as the super flu?) Twenty million people died in World War 1, while 20–50 million died of the super-flu. Note that the world population was less than 2 billion at that time. Depending on the estimates you use, this super-flu killed 1–2.5% of the world population. And that is the WORST flu pandemic we have record of. No, it isn’t the end of the world. It is a public health concern.

Past viral pandemics — some with death rates higher than COVID-19 — didn’t end the human race, so there’s no reason to think this one will. It will be a massive inconvenience, and it will make some people miserable for various reasons, and it will have some as-yet undetermined negative impact on world economy, but it’s definitely not the end of the world. We might even come out of it with some positives, like renewed respect and desire for good governance instead of obsession over political ideology; a renewed respect for genuine science over trutherism and denial; and renewed appreciation for all the people who really matter — doctors, scientists, delivery people, nurses, food service workers, family and so on — and diminished interest in vapid sports & entertainment celebrity and conspicuous consumption.

The novel coronavirus is currently FAR less lethal than the flu virus. However, coronaviruses mutate like crazy. The first was serious, then it mutated into an incredibly lethal virus. That said, the flu is not a coronavirus, and doesn’t mutate like a coronavirus. This novel coronavirus is much likelier to mutate like the common cold, and just be an annual blech. Understand this: mutation is random, and we don’t know what will happen, but so far so good.
